item.title: Top 1 top tipp on Linux
item.description: My personal top #1 tip for using the ubiquitous command line utility top is to press i when you have launched it. It will help you to see much more than before by eliminating idle processes. Pressing i helps a lot, because most of the time you start top to monitor processes which are putting (a lot) of load on your system and not for watching idle processes doing nothing.

item.description: I always felt a bit disappointed with most 3D printable smartphone and tablet stands out there. item.title: Awesome lists
item.description: Do you know what an awesome-list is? I am not talking about a shopping list, the movie Schindler's List or a piece of code with an array consisting of the names from all pokémon. I am talking about a best practice for naming community-curated lists of valuable things on the internet. If this sounds like a bookmark list to you, you're right. It is the same as a well-kept bookmark list for a certain topics, but with more than only one contributor and usually a strict policy for contributions to ensure constant quality.

item.title: About debugging with python's pdb and friends
item.description: I prepared some slides and a bit of demo code to demonstrate the python debugger pdb and how to work with this tool. This is meant to be a hands-on session at my local python user group meetup in Frankfurt am Main at wednesday night. item.title: Compare two or more remote files via SSH in vimdiff
item.description: A nice way to compare two (or more) files on different servers with vimdiff - which is just an alias for vim -d file1 file2 filex - works like that: $> vimdiff scp://remotehost//path/to/file1 scp://remotehost//path/to/file2 scp://remotehost//path/to/file3 Of course you can also compare files on localhost: $> vimdiff ./file1 scp://remotehost//path/to/file2 scp://remotehost//path/to/file3 Actually vimdiff is also a great difftool in tandem with git and other (D)VCS when you like to use the command line a lot.

item.title: 3D printed safety razor
item.description: About this posting I'm into safety razors and i'm also enthusiastic about 3D printing. A few days ago i stumbled upon this model of a safety razor from a user called H3R0M4T3 and printed it using ordinary white PLA and not expecting too much. The result after my first shave: I like this homebrew razor very much. It gives a very close shave and the razor itself can be positioned in various ways along the plate before it is compressed by the top cap which gives you either the same blade configuration on both or a quite aggressive blade on one side and a more gently blade on the other side.

item.title: Ad-hoc Webserver
item.description: Everybody who's using Python for some time knows about the SimpleHTTPServer module and its ability to act as an ad-hoc webserver: $> python2 -m SimpleHTTPServer 8080 Serving HTTP on 0.0.0.0 port 8080 ... Since we are all moving onwards to Python 3, this is how to do it after SimpleHTTPServer has been merged into http.server in Python 3: $> python3 -m http.server 8080 Serving HTTP on 0.0.0.0 port 8080 .

item.title: Use Dropbox for static file delivery
item.description: Not a new idea i guess, but a convenient and cost-efficient way to separate binary content from my blogs text and metadata is to copy all the images and other static data to dropbox and link to it with a public sharing link and the ?dl=1-parameter as described in this article at the dropbox help center. The benefits are: Workflow-friendly local file management, editing and syncing Always at least one local backup of all files on disk The structure of a shared link is consistent and easy to migrate if needed: https://www.

item.title: About me
item.description: My name is Stefan and i'm an information technoloy loving tinkerer. I have developed a passion for the so-called Internet of Things and artificial intelligence in distributed systems. In a broader sense this means that i'm interested in the ways networked technology can help us to improve life and society. On the contrary i'm also considering the possible threats and socio-cultural implications of interconnected systems. The balance between what is possible today and desirable in the long term has to be carefully considered.
